div.head: Summary
div.p: The Dhāraṇī of the Jewel Torch belongs to an extremely diverse Mahāyāna scriptural genre sometimes misleadingly translated as “incantation.” It is quite long, making up four traditional bam po units or forty-eight folios in the Degé edition and possessing several chapters or chapter-length main sections. In this text, after the bodhisattva Dharma­mati enters the meditative absorption called the infinite application of the bodhisattva’s jewel torch (dkon mchog ta la la’i ting nge ’dzin), millions of buddhas are summoned, who bless him and encourage him to teach. Thus inspired, Dharma­mati teaches the “ten categories” of a bodhisattva. A number of wonders follow, after which Dharma­mati is inspired to summarize the ten categories that he has just expounded, this time in verse.

In response to several ensuing requests to teach and the gathering of a vast assembly, the Buddha goes on to teach the mantra of the dhāraṇī. Most of the remainder of the text consists of a very long versified passage, in which the Buddha encourages bodhisattvas. Those final teachings, which I have divided into two chapters, begin and end with narrative passages spoken by the bodhisattva Bhadraśrī. Toward the beginning of this section, we find a passage on the virtues of faith, the best known (and in Tibet the most widely quoted) passage of this scripture, which had been quoted already in India by Śāntideva in his Training Anthology.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Translated by David Jackson. The translation benefitted immensely from the editorial acumen of Tom Tillemans. It was subsequently edited by David Higgins, Rory Lindsay, and Laura Goetz.

This study and translation focuses on the Mahāyāna scripture called The Dhāraṇī of the Jewel Torch. The body of texts known as dhāraṇī form a diverse Mahāyāna scriptural genre sometimes misleadingly translated as “incantation.” Most works of this class, which are usually short Mahāyāna sūtras or tantric texts, are included in the dhāraṇī section of the Kangyur. In the Degé edition of the Kangyur, this section comprises two hundred and sixty-four texts (Tōhoku nos. 846–1108). The present scripture is found there as Tōhoku no. 847,The present text (Toh 847), and all those contained in the same volume (gzungs ’dus, e), are listed as being located in volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by 84000 reading room—list this work as being located in volume 101. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the gzungs ‘dus section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalogue, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku catalogue placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the Vimalaprabhā­nāmakālacakra­tantraṭīkā (dus 'khor 'grel bshad dri med 'od, Toh 845), before the present volume, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur dkar chags (catalogue). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation. and is also found earlier, together with other Mahāyāna sūtras, as Tōhoku no. 145.
The Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism defines and explains dhāraṇī: The Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism, s.v. “dhāraṇī.”

q.p: In Sanskrit “mnemonic device,” “code.” The term is derived etymologically from the Sanskrit root √dhṛ (“to hold” or “to maintain”), thus suggesting something that supports, holds, or retains; hence, a verbal formula believed to “retain” or “encapsulate” the meaning of lengthier texts and prolix doctrines, thus functioning as a mnemonic device. It is said that those who memorize these formulae (which may or may not have semantic meaning) gain the power to retain the fuller teachings that the dhāraṇī “retain.” Commenting on the Bodhisattvabhūmisūtra [sic], Buddhist exegetes, such as the sixth-century Chinese scholiast Jinying Huiyuan, describe dhāraṇī as part of the equipment or accumulation (saṃbhāra) that bodhisattvas need to reach full enlightenment, and classify dhāraṇī into four categories, i.e., those associated with (1) teachings (dharma), (2) meaning (artha), (3) spells (mantra) and (4) acquiescence (kṣānti). The first two types are involved with learning and remembering the teachings and intent of Buddhist doctrine and thus function as “codes.” . . . The third type (mantradhāraṇī) helps the bodhisattva to overcome adversity, counter baleful influences, and bestow protection. . . . The fourth type assists the bodhisattva in acquiescing to the true nature of dharmas as unproduced . . . , giving him the courage to remain in the world for all sentient beings.

div.p: This informative dictionary entry ends by helpfully describing the various occurrences of dhāraṇī and suggesting that they are probably not to be considered proto-tantric texts (contrary to one prevailing theory) but rather belong to a pan-Buddhist context. However, the Indian Buddhist locus classicus for a fourfold division of dhāraṇīs is not a sūtra, as stated by that dictionary, but rather a treatise entitled the Bodhisattvabhūmi. The relevant passage was also discussed and translated by Jens Braarvig, See Braarvig 1985, p. 19–20: “The Bodhisattvabhūmi divides dhāraṇī into four types: dharmadhāraṇī [of Dharma], arthadhāraṇī [of the meaning], mantradhāraṇī [of mantras] and dhāraṇī to attain the tolerance, kṣānti, of a bodhisattva. By the first type the bodhisattva acquires the power of remembrance (smṛti) and insight (prajñā) into the Dharma, and thus is able to retain in memory for endless time any book merely by hearing it once. Arthadhāraṇī is the same, only here one retains the meaning of the book, not just the words, as in the first. . . . The third, mantradhāraṇī, at first seems to justify the translation ‘magical formula.’ Here, the bodhisattva acquires the power of concentration, samādhivaśitā, and he employs the mantras magically to alleviate the sufferings of living beings . . . the fourth, the bodhisattvakṣāntilabhāya dhāraṇī [dhāraṇī for attaining the bodhisattva’s tolerance] . . . consists in pondering a mantra until one understands its meaning, namely that it is without meaning, and accordingly understands all dharmas as being beyond expression. The bodhisattva's kṣānti is the tolerance of this state of things, that dharmas are unborn, empty and so on.” who renders this fourfold classification of dhāraṇī as (1) dhāraṇī of Dharma, (2) dhāraṇī of the meaning, (3) dhāraṇī of mantras, and (4) dhāraṇī to attain tolerance. Braarvig also cites the Akṣaya­matinirdeśa, which characterizes dhāraṇī as both remembrance itself and the faculty or means of retaining in memory the teachings of the buddhas. Braarvig 1985, p. 18. Braarvig thus observes that dhāraṇī became connected with concentration (samādhi), remembrance or recollection (smṛti), and meditation (dhyāna), concluding that “dhāraṇī and samādhi naturally belong together; to retain something in memory, concentration is needed, and remembrance may produce concentration.” Braarvig 1985, p. 22.

It should be noted that J. S. Negi in his dictionary entry for the phrase don gyi gzungs (dhāraṇī of the sense) quotes the same fourfold enumeration of dhāraṇī from the Bodhisattvabhūmi. See J. S. Negi 1993–2005, vol. 6, p. 2318: (1) dhāraṇī of the Dharma (chos kyi gzungs, dharmadhāraṇī), (2) dhāraṇī of the sense (don gyi gzungs, arthadhāraṇī), (3) dhāraṇī of mantras (gsang sngags kyi gzungs, mantradhāraṇī), and (4) bodhisattva’s dhāraṇī for gaining of forbearance, (byang chub sems dpa’ bzod pa ’thob par byed pa’i gzungs, bodhisattvakṣāntidhāraṇī). In a standard modern Tibetan–Chinese dictionary, moreover, the same four gzungs kyi sgo (access to the dhāraṇī) appear, but in a different order, while the third one is called tshig gi gzungs (dhāraṇī of words), instead of chos kyi gzungs (dhāraṇī of Dharma). See Krang Dbyi-sun 1985, p. 2506.

The topic of dhāraṇī has also received notable attention from Janet Gyatso, who provides a rich semiotic analysis focusing on the work of the Tibetan author Dodrupchen Jikten Tenpai Nyima This is the phonetic rendering of the Tibetan name rdo grub chen ’jigs med bstan pa’i nyi ma. (1865–c. 1926). Drawing on the theories of Charles Sanders Peirce, Gyatso argues that dhāraṇī function as “iconic signifiers” that represent their signified objects by virtue of being similar to them. See Gyatso 1992, p. 179. Noting common examples of iconic signifiers such as pictures, diagrams, and metaphors, she argues that dhāraṇīs are analogous to these since—following the explanation of Dodrupchen—their lack of any conventional meaning is in fact their meaning: “Again, as the mantric formula itself has no linguistically expressible meaning, it resembles the thusness that it is signifying, and so it can be employed as an iconic sign.” Gyatso 1992, p. 191. Here the idea is that dhāraṇī qua iconic signs can free practitioners from their own deluded conventions, functioning as “reminders” of inexpressible emptiness. The assumption is that deluded sentient beings forget the “profound situation” of emptiness, and gradually may become accustomed to indexical and symbolic signs that come to be understood as “icons of that birthless truth.” Gyatso 1992, p. 195.

Ronald Davidson On the different meanings of dhāraṇī and the Western scholarly reception of the term, see Davidson 2009. argues that dhāraṇī are “codings” for different elements of Buddhist tradition including doctrines, syllables, scriptures, ritual powers, the elimination of negative karma, the destruction of unwholesome psychological states, essential elements of the Buddhist path, and even the path in its entirety. In this regard, he criticizes his predecessors for limiting their analyses of dhāraṇī to intellective and mnemonic functions. Davidson 2009, p. 106. He also recognizes dhāraṇī as a scriptural genre, describing it as an extremely diverse phenomenon:

q.p: Dhāraṇīs are phrases/statements/texts that operate in the same manner as dhāraṇīs as syllables/letters or as mantras, from coding elements of doctrine to the entire canon to acting as a vehicle for final liberation. This function yields dhāraṇīs as a genre, which often includes prayers, aspirations, ritual programs and concluding summaries of benefits. It is indicative, though, that texts in the genre can have their mantradhāraṇīs abstracted elsewhere with no sense that there is a loss of the meaning, just what we might expect for coded information. See Davidson 2009, p. 142.

div.p: Davidson prefaces these characterizations of dhāraṇī by cautioning that the volume and proliferation of dhāraṇī scriptures and dhāraṇī-related rites necessitate that any statement concerning dhāraṇīs “requires qualification almost before it is written.” Davidson 2009, p. 141. He notes that this situation is exacerbated by the fact that Mahāyāna sūtras “sometimes contradict each other and, occasionally, themselves.” Davidson 2009, p. 141.

In his second article on dhāraṇī, Davidson takes a different approach, using the linguistic tools of historical pragmatics. Drawing on the work of John Searle, Davidson explores how dhāraṇī texts might be fruitfully analyzed as consisting of illocutionary acts. He finds nine forms of such acts in his sources: (1) precipitating assertives that articulate a problem condition or a miraculous event, (2) directives to speak or perform the dhāraṇī, with the verb in the imperative or optative, (3) commissive statements promising to communicate a dhāraṇī, (4) assertives in the forms of precedent or predictive statements extolling the use of the given dhāraṇī by a/some/many previous buddhas, (5) assertives as benefit statements that usually concern the dhāraṇī’s power to ward off disease, poison, possession, or enemies, or that affirm health, welfare, or soteriological efficacy, (6) assertive hybrid warning statements, (7) ubiquitous expressives such as praise, homage, confession, and condemnation, (8) perlocutionary expressives or assertives about the joy and amazement of the audience who received the dhāraṇī under discussion, and (9) the mantradhāraṇī itself. See Davidson 2014, p. 11. By identifying these nine types of illocutionary acts across his source texts, Davidson concludes that the dhāraṇī genre is highly formalized—and to some degree formulaic—working in recognizable pragmatic patterns. Davidson 2014, p. 52.

Gyatso’s and Davidson’s characterizations of dhāraṇī are relevant to The Dhāraṇī of the Jewel Torch, in which we find frequent references to the ultimate reality of emptiness and the various codings and speech acts that Davidson outlines. The text is quite long, making up four traditional bam po units or forty-eight folios in the Degé edition and with four or five chapters or chapter-length main sections. Its setting is the Vulture Peak of Rājagṛha. Its audience comprises a great gathering of highly accomplished fully ordained monks and a large congregation of bodhisattvas, thirty-three of whom are named and all of whom have reached very high levels of Mahāyāna practice and attainment. The main interlocutor at the beginning is the bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra, who prominently appears at the head of the list of eminent bodhisattvas. Here he makes a second appearance, reverently approaching the Buddha and asking: “Blessed One, how should we understand dharmadhātu?”

The Buddha’s answer begins: “Son of a good family, the dharmadhātu is to be understood as a non-entity.” This answer thus reveals that the doctrinal content and context of this scripture is the Mahāyāna, where the ultimate “realm of reality” (dharmadhātu) is conceived in terms of the Madhyamaka doctrine of emptiness (śūnyavāda).

Soon after that, the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī also appears as an important interlocutor, requesting the Buddha to teach this dhāraṇī. The Buddha defers, insisting that the bodhisattva should request it from Samanta­bhadra, which Mañjuśrī, after some hesitation, finally agrees to do.
The first question that Mañjuśrī asks Samanta­bhadra is a fundamental one: “O son of the victors, what is the basic meaning behind calling the Buddha ‘Buddha’?”

The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra answers: “O son of the victors, the basic meaning of buddha is groundlessness. The basic meaning of buddha is the meaning of non-entity.” His answer resembles in its content the answer the Buddha had given him shortly before about dharmadhātu.

After a brief interlude in which the venerable śrāvaka Śāradvatī­putra (also known as Śāriputra) talks with Mañjuśrī without showing any insight, the bodhisattva Dharma­mati makes his appearance. That bodhisattva in due course enters the meditative absorption called the infinite application of the bodhisattva’s jewel torch, which is closely linked with the main theme of the whole sūtra. As soon as he enters that concentration, millions of buddhas are summoned; they bless him and encourage him to summon the eloquence to teach.

Thus inspired, Dharma­mati teaches the ten categories of the bodhisattva (F.40.a–45.b), just as he was requested, in the long passage that follows. A number of wonders then occur, after which the same bodhisattva is inspired to speak again, this time in verse, where he summarizes in verse the ten categories that he has just expounded.

Thereafter, in response to several ensuing requests to teach and the gathering of a vast assembly, the Buddha briefly teaches the mantra of the dhāraṇī (F.54.b). By then Śāradvatī­putra reappears and demonstrates deep insight into the Mahāyāna.

A long section requested by Mañjuśrī (F.56.a–60.a), almost a chapter in its own right, follows that and explains the benefits that hearing this sūtra will have for future disciples. Here several stark warnings are given to future hearers (mainly future monks) who might one day criticize or reject this sūtra. In one memorable passage the Buddha advises those critics to accept this teaching just like they would accept the Kāraṇḍavyūha Sūtra. The exact words are: “you should view this king among sūtras as like, for instance, the Kāraṇḍavyūha Sūtra.”

The final main section of the sūtra is a very long passage (twenty folios in the Degé edition) of versified encouragement for bodhisattvas that is spoken by the Buddha. This final versified section is introduced by a prologue featuring Ānanda. The main versified part (F.63.a–81.a) begins and ends with narrative passages that introduce and conclude the teachings of the bodhisattva Bhadraśrī, who is mentioned together with many “lions of men” (mi yi seng ge) or lay rulers. Bhadraśrī is asked at the start to teach about the good qualities and modes of conduct of the bodhisattva. The remaining teachings are spoken by him. Saying he will explain just a few examples or comparisons, he first eulogizes the thought of awakening (bodhicitta) and then a few verses later praises faith in a well-known passage that was quoted by Śāntideva in his Training Anthology (F.63.b–64.b). In chapter 5, Bhadraśrī touches on many other subjects besides faith, such as different kinds of light rays, the qualities and astounding visual and other sensory content of the Buddha’s meditative absorptions, and comparisons with the powerful magical displays of the ordinary gods such as Indra and the king of the nāgas.

That the text was traditionally deemed to possess chapters or chapter-like internal divisions is demonstrated by a passage near the end of chapter 3: “Here ends the chapter in which the special virtues of The Jewel Torch Dhāraṇī were taught in detail.” The Tibetan editors clearly indicate the ends of bam po sections, thus providing me (unusually) some hints of where to break the chapters (though bam po units do not typically refer to chapter divisions).

div.head: Method of Translation
div.p: This translation is based principally on the Comparative Edition of the Kangyur (dpe bsdur ma), which takes the Degé edition as its main source. Yeshé Dé’s translation contains a few archaic words, as one would expect in a translation dating to the early ninth century, that survived the extensive editing and spelling modernization that it must have undergone long before the eighteenth-century Degé xylograph edition was produced. This was prepared under the editorial leadership of Situ Panchen, who put a final polish on the work. I record below in the endnotes a few noteworthy archaic spellings. One prominent archaic word is the ta la la used in the title instead of the more usual sgron me (“torch,” “lamp”). We also find the archaic verb byin (F.37.a) as a verb of the Buddha’s speech, which seems not to be anywhere attested though I have found it in several other sūtras. Another archaic word is dbung (“center”), which (found on F.45.a) is a word not found in either Goldstein or Inagaki. Negi says it is a synonym of dbus, and it must be archaic. Negi also notes the similar (rare) verb dbung ba (=khro ba). The other archaic spellings include the spelling mnod pa (prahaṇam) =nod pa, (“to receive”), an old spelling found in Negi.

In a few passages where the Degé contains an apparent mistake in sense (such as a missing or superfluous negative), I have suggested a change in the text reading in an endnote, often in consultation with the Stok Palace version. Internal consistency of the meaning was for me decisive in such cases.

Portions of a Sanskrit version are preserved in the form of long quotations in Śāntideva’s Training Anthology (Śikṣāsamuccaya). Of the two quotations from this dhāraṇī in the Śikṣāsamuccaya, the first is in the first chapter (on the perfection of giving) and describes the virtues of faith. See Goodman 2016, p. 3–5. The second quotation appears in chapter 18, which treats the recollection of the Three Jewels. See Goodman 2016, p. 304–322. The research catalog and bibliography of the Nyingma edition of the Degé Kangyur and Tengyur See The Nyingma Edition of the sDe-dge bKa’-’gyur and bsTan-’gyur, 1977–1983, p. 341. refers to a “fragmentary German translation of Śikṣāsamuccaya” It is worth noting that the same Nyingma catalog also mentions the existence of a Śikṣāsamuccaya manuscript in the Peking Imperial Palace (11.3245) that is reproduced in the Śata-piṭaka (STP) series. This must refer to Lokesh Chandra and Raghu Vira 1966–1976, Sanskrit texts from the imperial palace at Peking, in the Manchurian, Chinese, Mongolian and Tibetan scripts. It, too, was not considered essential for producing the present translation from Tibetan. by M. Winternitz in a single two-page passage on the power of belief from his 1930 book on Mahāyāna Buddhism according to Sanskrit and Prakrit texts. See Winternitz, 1930.

Śāntideva’s entire work was first translated into English by Cecil Bendall and W. H. D. Rouse in 1981, but that translation has many errors and is therefore of limited usefulness. See Goodman 2016, p. xxxii. The work was very recently translated again into English by Charles Goodman. Goodman 2016. My translation of the relevant section from the Tibetan departs in many respects from Goodman’s. Though Goodman did field work in Sarnath (See Goodman 2016, p. lxxi) he seems not to know the sixteen-volume Tibetan-Sanskrit dictionary by J. S. Negi that was published there between 1993 and 2005, which used the Śikṣāsamuccaya as one of its sources. He thus overlooked several Indian names such as Tumburu. For example, in one difficult passage that refers to a divine muse of musicians whose propitiation leads to better playing, the passage begins by alluding to Sarasvatī, a daughter of Brahmā with a sweet voice. Goodman translates: “A woman with a sweet voice who plays the tamboura/ Gives the impression of being a daughter of Brahmā.” See Goodman 2016, p. 344. This is an unconvincing translation because the main point of the long passage is to make favorable comparisons with even the great and powerful gods. Here the sweet-voiced goddess Sarasvatī (called dbyangs ldan ma instead of the usual dbyangs can ma) is clearly mentioned, as a goddess who is famed for granting beauty in song or poetry to those who practice austerities in her honor. I translate the two somewhat convoluted verses:

lg.l: Tumburu’s wife Sarasvatī,
That daughter of Brahmā sprung from his mind,
Who enters the minds of those who like truth and vow not to cause harm,
And who influences the avenues of their thoughts and minds and mouths—
If even that sweet-voiced goddess, desirous and angry,
Can please the world using her beautiful speech,
Which is an element of voice in harmony with practiced austerities,
Why could those who are rich with the qualities of gnosis not do so?

div.p: There is a Chinese version (Taishō 299), which was translated by Fatian (Fa-t’ien) in the year 983, See entry in The Korean Buddhist Canon: A Descriptive Catalogue, http://www.acmuller.net/descriptive_catalogue/files/k1095.html. but it was not considered essential for producing this translation.

div.head: Tibetan Translator
div.p: According to the translation colophon, this sūtra was translated into Tibetan, checked, and established by the Indian master Surendra­bodhi and the chief-editor translator the monk Yeshé Dé.

div.head: Tibetan Reception and Quotations
div.p: The sūtra has occasionally been quoted by Tibetan authors, its passage on the kinds of faith being the most commonly quoted. I found the title wrongly cited as the dkon mchog ta la’i gzungs (instead of ta la la’i) in the Tenrim Chenmo (bstan rim chen mo). This may show that the word ta la la in the title was unfamiliar to them, if it was not simply a scribal error. See Drolungpa Lodrö Jungné, bstan rim chen mo, vol. 2, fol. 61a: dkon mchog ta la las kyang / dad pa sngon ’gro ma ltar skyed pa ste // yon tan thams cad bsrung zhing ’phel bar byed // dad pa nor dang gter dang rkang pa’i mchog / lag pa bzhin du dag sdud rtsa ba yin / zhes bya ba la sogs pa mang du gsungs so//. One similarly finds it in a standard history of the Jonangpa. See Dzamthang Lama Ngawang Lodrö Drakpa, dpal ldan jo nang pa’i chos ’byung (=jo nang chos ’byung) 1992, pp. 557–558: dkon mchog ta la la’i gzungs las ’di ltar gsungs pa ste / dad pa sngon ’gro ma ltar bskyed pa ste / / yon tan thams cad bsrung zhing ’phel bar byed / / dogs pa sel zhing chu bo rnams sgrol / / dad pa bde legs grong khyer mtshon byed yin / / dad pa rnyog pa mes cing sems dad byed / / nga rgyal spong zing gus pa’i rtsa ba yin / / dad pa nor dang gter dang rkang pa’i mchog / / lag pa bzhin du dge sdug rtsa ba yin / / dad pas yongs su gtong la dga’ bar byed / / dad pas rgyal ba’i chos la rab dga’ bskyed / / dad pas yon tan ye shes khyad par ’phags / / sangs rgyas go ’phang thob cing ’thob par byed / / ces gsungs shing / /.
The text is sometimes cited as the dkon mchog sgron ma, or even more commonly dkon mchog sgron me’i mdo, old alternative Tibetan renderings of the same Sanskrit title.

div.head: The Translation
The Mahāyāna Sūtra
The Dhāraṇī of the Jewel Torch
Chapter 1
div.p: Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas!

Thus did I hear at one time. The Blessed One was dwelling on the Vulture Peak of Rājagṛha, seated together with a great gathering of fully ordained monks including more than one thousand fully ordained monks, all of whom possessed virtuous qualities, roared mighty lion’s roars as great teachers, and were expert in seeking an immeasurable accumulation of gnosis.

A great gathering of bodhisattvas was also assembled there, including the bodhisattva great beings Samanta­bhadra, Ratna­mudrā­hasta, Nityodyukta, the bodhisattva Ornamented by Good Qualities, Announcing Merits, Mahāmati, Array of Good Qualities, Vajra Intelligence, Vajragarbha, Light of a Vajra, Weapon of a Vajra, Adamantine Vajra, Dhāraṇī­dhara, Dhāraṇī­mati, Seeing All Purposes, Avaloki­teśvara, Mahā­sthāmaprāpta, Dṛḍhamati, Vajrapāṇi, Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta, Avoiding Evil Destinies, Overcoming All Sorrow and Darkness, Suvikrānta­vikrāmin, Not Taking or Rejecting, Essence of Sandalwood, Sāgara­mati, Durabhi­sambhava, Arising Joy, Intelligence of Conduct, Pratibhākūṭa, Essence of Speed, and Maitreya.

Those and other bodhisattva great beings all dwelled in inconceivable liberation, had reached emancipation Tib. nges par byung ba; Skt. niṣkrānta. The Comparative Edition notes that the Yongle, Lithang, Kangxi, and Choné read nges par ’byung ba (p. 207). through the meditative absorption heroic progress, had unimpeded melodic voices, and were skilled in holding sway over limitless buddha realms. They all dwelled in fearlessness, were devoid of attachment and anger, possessed pleasant-sounding voices, were not attached to the three realms of existence, possessed undivided retinues of attendants, were arisen from omniscience, and possessed limitless meditative absorptions and meditative attainments. They all fulfilled every hope, experienced the perfection of discriminating wisdom, were inclined toward meaningful goals in their bodily, verbal, and mental deeds, were intent on omniscience, were blessed to have limitless Tib. tshad med par. The Comparative Edition notes that the Narthang and Lhasa editions read tshad med pas, which seems preferable (p. 207). The Stok Palace version also reads tshad med pas (fol. 149b6). meditative absorptions and conduct, had attained fearlessness, had emptiness as their sphere of experience, Tib. stong pa nyid spyod yul ba. The Comparative Edition observes that the Narthang and Lhasa editions read stong pa nyid kyi spyod yul ba (p. 207). The Stok Palace also reads stong pa nyid kyi spyod yul ba (fol. 149b6). and dwelled in the absence of phenomenal marks.

Then the bodhisattva great being Samanta­bhadra, who was seated as part of that assembly, bowing with his head to the feet of the Blessed One, said: “Blessed One, how should we understand dharmadhātu?”

The Blessed One answered: “Son of a good family, the dharmadhātu is to be understood as a non-entity. Son of a good family, you should understand dharmadhātu as follows: as space-like, as without conceptual elaborations, as unelaborated, as without accepting, as without rejecting, as a non-entity, and as foundationless.”
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra asked: “Blessed One, does dharmadhātu arise?”

The Blessed One answered: “Son of a good family, dharmadhātu has no arising. Son of a good family, the dharmadhātu is inconceivable. You should understand it as a non-entity: entities are in no way expressible, nor can they be shown in any way.”
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra asked: “Blessed One, how many aspects does awakening have?”
The Blessed One answered: “Son of a good family, the aspects of awakening are measureless; they cannot be shown to have a fixed measure.”
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra asked: “Blessed One, can dharmadhātu be conceptualized?”
The Blessed One answered: “Son of a good family, dharmadhātu is nonconceptual.”
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra asked: “If dharmadhātu is nonconceptual, how then can spiritually immature ordinary people understand it?”
The Blessed One answered: “All spiritually immature ordinary people are just the products of thought, ratiocination, and imagination.”
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said: “Blessed One, the awakening of the tathāgatas is profound.”
The Blessed One said: “So it is. As you say, son of a good family. Moreover, the fact that all phenomena are without conceptual elaborations is what is called awakening.”

Then Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta, who had already arrived at that assembly and was already seated, bowed his head to the Blessed One’s feet and addressed him with these words: “I request that the Blessed One explain The Dhāraṇī of the Jewel Torch.”

The Blessed One answered: “Son of a good family, ask the bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra. He possesses eloquent confidence that is unhindered with respect to all dharmas. Here “all dharmas” (Tib. chos thams cad; Skt. sarvadharma) denotes both teachings and matters taught. He will teach it to you.”
Then Mañjuśrī seated himself directly facing the Blessed One with palms joined in supplication and said: “Why cannot the Blessed One himself, who is omniscient and all-seeing, explain it?”
The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, where there is a bodhisattva who possesses such excellent qualities, there the tathāgatas remain neutral.”
Mañjuśrī said: “Blessed One, tathāgatas do not remain neutral.”
The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, I am not abandoning the realm of sentient beings. Nevertheless, the teaching of the bodhisattvas is an immeasurable and inconceivable teaching.”
Then Mañjuśrī repeated: “I request the Blessed One to explain The Dhāraṇī of the Jewel Torch.”
The Blessed One answered: “Son of a good family, ask the bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra! He will teach it to you. Why? Because that sublime man dwells in the assemblage of gnosis.”
Mañjuśrī said: “If the Tathāgata intends that for me, I will request it from that sublime man.”

The Blessed One said: “Mañjuśrī, if you have attained as many meditative absorptions as there are atoms, what need is there for you to request it from the Tathāgata? Son of a good family, you possess fortunate endowments regarding all qualities of a buddha.”
Mañjuśrī said: “Blessed One, all the qualities of a buddha that I have relied on, cultivated, and enhanced should be understood as the power of the person of the Tathāgata.”
The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, excellent, excellent! You have spoken well. But I request you, Mañjuśrī, to ask the bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra to teach.”
Then Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta said to the Blessed One: “This bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra teaches the exceedingly profound. He has mastered the Mahāyāna.”

The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, you, too, are a king whose might extends over all dharmas. I.e., the teachings and phenomena. Don’t ask me. You also possess the inconceivable meditative absorption of abiding in emptiness.”

Then Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta respectfully paid homage to the bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra, pressing the ten fingers of his hands together and saying to him: “O son of the victors, if you grant me the occasion, I would like to ask you a few words.”
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said: “Son of a good family, if you know it to be a timely matter, ask!”
Then Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta said this to the bodhisattva and great being Samanta­bhadra: “O son of the victors, what is the basic meaning behind calling the Buddha ‘Buddha’?”

The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said: “O son of the victors, the basic meaning of buddha is groundlessness. Tib. gzhi med pa’i don. The Stok Palace version reads med pa’i don “the meaning of nonexistence” (fol. 152a3). The basic meaning of buddha is the absence of entities. The basic meaning of buddha is inconceivability. The basic meaning of buddha is to be equal to the unequaled. Note that Tib. mi mnyam pa dang mnyam pa; Skt. asamasama means, according to Inagaki, “equal to the unequaled.” According to Edgerton, it means “unequalled,” lit. “having no equal like him.” The basic meaning of buddha is the absence of conceptual elaborations. The basic meaning of buddha is unelaborated. The basic meaning of buddha is the absence of accepting. The basic meaning of buddha is the absence of rejecting. The basic meaning of buddha is space-like. The basic meaning of buddha is ineffability. Son of a good family, such is the nature of the qualities of a buddha.”

Mañjuśrī said: “O son of the victors, but if all phenomena are without conceptual elaborations, how can you teach ‘qualities of a buddha’?” Note that the Stok Palace version has zhes instead of shes (fol. 152a7), which we follow here.
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said: “O son of the victors, such a ‘teaching’ is unteachable.”
Mañjuśrī said: “O son of the victors, if it is unteachable, what is taught?”
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said: “Mañjuśrī, that which is the unteachable is taught through designation.”
Mañjuśrī said: “O son of the victors, what does one designate through designation?”
The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said: “Mañjuśrī, through designation one designates neither entities nor non-entities.”
Mañjuśrī said: “O son of the victors, if one does not designate entities through designation and does not designate non-entities either, then how could the Three Vehicles ever be taught?”

The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said: “Mañjuśrī, don’t be attached to the dharmadhātu, which is free of attachment! Why not? Mañjuśrī, it is because the Tathāgata taught that all phenomena are non-entities. Why are they non-entities? It is because the five aggregates are not apprehended.” Tib. dmigs pa med pa. The Comparative Edition notes that the Narthang and Lhasa editions read mi dmigs pa (p. 208). The Stok Palace version also reads mi dmigs pa (fol. 152a5).
Mañjuśrī asked: “Is awakening something with conceptual elaborations? Or is it something that is without conceptual elaborations?”

The bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said: “Son of a good family, awakening is neither something with conceptual elaborations, nor is it something that is without conceptual elaborations. Thus, awakening exists neither in terms of having elaborations nor as being devoid of elaborations; it is indivisible into two.”

Then the Blessed One said Note that here Tib. byin, an archaic verb, is used with the meaning to say or speak. to the bodhisattva great being Samanta­bhadra: “Son of a good family, this inconceivable teaching is excellent, excellent! Yet, through the teaching of this discourse, the world with its gods will become confused.”
Mañjuśrī said: “Blessed One, such a teaching of Dharma is not suitable for being understood.”
The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, so it is, just as you say.”
Then Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta said to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, are all phenomena designated by this type of designation?”
The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, so it is, just as you say.”

Then the bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra said to the Blessed One: “This authentic access to the Dharma Tib. rnam par dag pa’i sgo. I have here added “the Dharma” for the sake of clarity. is difficult to appreciate!”
The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, so it is, just as you say.”
Then the bodhisattva Sāgara­mati said to the Blessed One: “This authentic access to the Dharma that was taught by the bodhisattva Samanta­bhadra was well expressed.”

The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, so it is, just as you say. Moreover, son of a good family, this is the natural result Tib. rgyu mthun pa. The Comparative Edition follows the Degé and others by including rgyu ’thun pa, though the more common spelling rgyu mthun pa is reflected in the Kangxi, Narthang, Lhasa, and Stok Palace versions. See Comparative Edition, p. 208; Stok Palace, fol. 153b1. of all phenomena. It is a great rain of the Dharma.”

Then a brahmin who was like a great śāla tree Tib. sā la. The Comparative Edition notes that the Yongle, Lithang, Kangxi, and Choné read sa la (p. 208). The Stok Palace version reads sā la (fol. 153b1). and who dwelled in equality said: “Blessed One, awakening is an inconceivable equality. No letters or words are perceived in it.”
The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, so it is; in the dharmadhātu no words are perceived, nor is any sense data perceived.”
Then Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta said to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, what is the natural result of emptiness? What is its aspect? What is its sign? What is its phenomenal mark?”

The Blessed One said: “Mañjuśrī, emptiness is inexpressible and ineffable. That which partakes of its inexpressible nature is what is called emptiness. Emptiness is without letters, and thus it is called emptiness. Emptiness is ineffable, and hence it is called emptiness. Son of a good family, all phenomena are empty of their own essential nature.”
Then the venerable Śāradvatī­putra said to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, look at the magical displays of the bodhisattvas who dwell in the inconceivable reality.”

The Blessed One said: “Venerable Śāradvatī­putra, the knowledge of a bodhisattva who first generates the thought of awakening is superior, but the knowledge of an arhat is not as good. Why not? It is because arhats dwell far removed from the qualities of a buddha, and because that bodhisattva will become a blessed buddha.”

Then the bodhisattva and great being Sarva­dharmeśvara said to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, according to my understanding of the sense of what the Blessed One has taught, the śrāvakas have simply not obtained the qualities of a śrāvaka.”

The Blessed One said: “Son of a good family, it is not that śrāvakas have not obtained the qualities of a śrāvaka. Nonetheless, how could a śrāvaka answer questions together with bodhisattvas or have the power and potency to bring about a transformation of their conduct?”

Then Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta said to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, if the Tathāgata taught that this Śāradvatī­putra was best among those of his disciples possessing discriminating wisdom, what did that teaching reveal?”
The Blessed One said: “Mañjuśrī, what I taught was without teaching.”
Then Mañjuśrī Kumāra­bhūta said to the elder Śāradvatī­putra: “Elder, did you obtain the qualities of a śrāvaka?”
He answered: “No, I did not.”
Mañjuśrī said: “In that case, are you an ordinary person?”
“No.”
“So, are you a trainee?”
“No.”
“Are you the best among those who possess discriminating wisdom?”
“No.”

Mañjuśrī said: “Elder Śāradvatī­putra, if you are neither an ordinary person nor a trainee nor best among those possessing discriminating wisdom, that can only mean you are someone who adheres to a heretical view.” Here we have the very rare term: Tib. dmigs pa can; Skt. aupalambhika, which refers to someone with a heretical view according to Edgerton.
Śāradvatī­putra said: “Son of a good family, I am not going to debate with you, a sublime person whose profound depth is as unfathomable as the ocean.”
Mañjuśrī said: “Honorable Śāradvatī­putra, don’t say that! You are the most senior of elders.”

The elder said: “The fact of my old age will not itself achieve anything, nor will it lead to realization. To make it better understood, son of a good family, I will give you an example. Consider how a great boulder may be destroyed even by means of a small diamond. Likewise, the discriminating wisdom that you have in a single pore of your body is more than a sentient being like myself has in every atom of my body. Son of a good family, to make it understood, I will use another example for you. It is like, for instance, how a powerful man can, with just a small iron hook, tame a huge frightful elephant. Son of good family, likewise, you possess power. I am weak. How can I debate with a great elephant like this?”

Then the elder Śāradvatī­putra said to the Blessed One: “Blessed One, it is like this: if a blind man cannot follow after someone or see a city, how would he manage to go from house to house? That would be impossible. Similarly, I see myself as blind in the presence of great elephants like these. The qualities of a buddha are that vast. I am not a suitable vessel for the qualities of a buddha. Now there is nothing for me to do.”

The Blessed One said: “Śāradvatī­putra, don’t talk like that! Consider, for example, that however many sentient beings may be touched by light from a tathāgata, all will obtain the qualities of a buddha. Likewise, Śāradvatī­putra, you will be a recipient of limitless and inconceivable meditative absorptions.”
When the Blessed One explained this Dharma discourse, ninety-two thousand among the gods and humans gained a clear understanding of the Dharma.

Then the bodhisattva Dharma­mati entered the meditative absorption called the infinite application of the bodhisattva’s jewel torch absorption. No sooner had the bodhisattva Dharma­mati entered that absorption, then from beyond the whole range of particles comprising the atoms of ten thousand buddhafields of the world systems in each of the ten directions, blessed buddhas numbering as many as the atoms of ten thousand buddhafields showed their faces. They all had the same name: Vajra Quintessence.

As though they were in just one place despite issuing from the ten directions, those blessed buddhas said to him: “Dharma­mati, your entering into the absorption of the bodhisattva’s infinite application of absorption is excellent, excellent! Son of a good family, it is like this. Through the previous aspiration and blessing of this blessed one and the tathāgata Vairocana himself, and through being fortified by your own roots of virtue, all the buddhas from the ten directions, numbering as many as the atoms in ten thousand buddhafields, and every one with the same name, bless you, so that you teach all Dharma teachings, prepare for the gnosis of the Buddha, increase the gnosis of the Buddha, enter into the dharmadhātu, liberate the realms of sentient beings, enter and penetrate unbound gnosis, engage with gnosis, speak all languages, enter into omniscient gnosis, become unobstructed with respect to all phenomena, and engage in teaching the Dharma through knowing all three times. Through the strength and blessing of the Buddha, expound the Dharma with inspired speech, beginning with the ten categories of the bodhisattva!” Tib. byang chub sems dpa’ rnam par gzhag pa bcu. The term rnam par gzhag pa probably renders Skt. vyavasthāna, which can also mean “differentiation” (see Edgerton) i.e., “classification,” and by association, “category” and the “distinctive features” of each category. Hence, here it is “the ten categories of the bodhisattva.”

Then those blessed buddhas caused that blessed bodhisattva Dharma­mati to attain the light of endless gnosis, with a nature that was free of obstruction, free of impediment, and not forgetful; a gnosis free from differentiation, with a nature that was morally blameless, inviolable, dauntless, inalienable; and excellent speech. Why so? Because he had thus obtained the nature of that absorption.

Then those blessed buddhas extended their right hands and touched Tib. nyug pa is an old term meaning “to touch,” according to Negi. the head of the bodhisattva Dharma­mati. As soon as those blessed buddhas had touched the bodhisattva Dharma­mati, he rose from that absorption and said to the bodhisattvas: “O sons of the victors, this family of bodhisattvas is as follows: it is vast owing to the boundlessness of the dharmadhātu and of the element of space. O sons of the victors, the bodhisattva great beings were born into the family of past blessed buddhas, future blessed buddhas, and present blessed buddhas.”

Then those bodhisattvas said to the bodhisattva Dharma­mati: “O son of the victors, who are those bodhisattva great beings who were born into the family of the past, future, and present blessed buddhas? Tell me what thought they came from. O son Note that we should here read this as Tib. sras (singular) rather than sras dag (plural). of the victors, explain what those ten categories of bodhisattvas are!”

The bodhisattva Dharma­mati said to those bodhisattvas: “O sons of the victors, ten categories of bodhisattvas were taught, are taught, and will be taught by buddhas of the past, present, and future. What are those ten? They are: (1) a bodhisattva who has first generated the thought of awakening, (2) a beginner, (3) one who engages in yogic practice, (4) one who has taken rebirth, (5) one who has perfected application, (6) one who has perfected intention, (7) one who is irreversible, (8) one who is still a youth, Tib. gzhon nur gyur pa. Skt. Kumāra­bhūta according to Edgerton, “while still a youth/remaining a youth.” (9) one who is a regent, and (10) one who has been consecrated. O sons of the victors, those ten categories of bodhisattvas were taught, are taught, and will be taught by buddhas of the past, present, and future.

(1) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who has first generated the thought of awakening? O sons of the victors, this bodhisattva who has first generated the thought of awakening will, upon seeing the blessed buddhas, see an excellent or beautiful form with a completely excellent and brilliant complexion, Tib. kha dog bzang po rgyas pa'am/ rgya che ba'am/ gzi brjid che ba'am. I am reading rgyas pa, rgya che ba, and gzi brjid che ba as modifiers of kha dog bzang po. or miracles of magical displays, miracles of mind reading, See Tib. kun tu brjod pa’i cho ’phrul; Skt. ādeśanā-prātihārya," as explained in Edgerton. or miracles of insightful admonition. I.e., miracles of insightful admonition effecting destruction of one’s vices. See Tib. rjes si bstan pa’i cho ’phrul; Skt. anuśāseniprātihārya, as explained in Edgerton. Or else, having seen suffering sentient beings or having heard the praises of the Tathāgata, such a being will desire all-knowing gnosis and from the very beginning generate the intention to attain the highest insuperable awakening. And with that very first generation of the intention to attain awakening, that being will uphold ten things that are difficult to develop. What are those ten? They are: (1) the knowledge of what is possible and impossible, On “possible” and “impossible” for Tib. gnas dang mi gnas; Skt. sthānāsthāna, see Edgerton. (2) the knowledge of deeds The Comparative Edition notes that the Yongle, Lithang, Kangxi, and Choné versions omit las dang (pp. 208–209). that occur in the past, present, and future and qualities that were obtained, (3) the knowledge of everywhere that paths lead, (4) the knowledge of numerous varied constituents of beings, (5) the knowledge of numerous spiritual inclinations and liberations, (6) the knowledge of the superior and inferior faculties, (7) the knowledge of the meditative concentrations, emancipations, absorptions, and meditative attainments in their defiled and purified forms and their arising, Tib. ldang ba. The Comparative Edition notes that the Narthang and Lhasa versions here read ldan pa (p. 209). The Stok Palace version also reads ldan pa (fol. 157b4). (8) the knowledge that remembers previous lives, (9) the knowledge of the divine eye, and (10) the knowledge of the exhaustion of defilements. Thus, they will uphold those ten things that are difficult to develop. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who has first generated the thought of awakening.

“O sons of the victors, this bodhisattva great being who has first generated the thought of awakening should worship the Buddha and apply the requisites for a bodhisattva’s happiness. Concerning that, he should provide explanations on becoming the lord of the world, acting sublimely, not being outshone, meeting with an immeasurable number of buddhas, engaging in yogic practice in the absorption of complete pacification, turning back the wheel of saṃsāra, setting in motion the wheel of the holy Dharma, and protecting suffering sentient beings. Why so? It is because upon generating the thought of awakening, he applies himself for the most part to all the qualities of a buddha, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who has first generated the thought of awakening.

(2) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the beginning bodhisattva? Tib. las dang po pa’i byang chub sems dpa’ rnam par gzhag pa. O sons of the victors, this beginning bodhisattva has from the start generated ten aspects of mind. What are the ten aspects? They are: (1) a mind that bring benefit, (2) a mind that brings happiness, (3) a mind of kindness, (4) a mind that is flexible, (5) a mind that feels sadness, (6) a mind that intends to help, (7) a mind that aims at protecting everyone, (8) a mind of equality, (9) a mind of becoming a teacher, (10) and a mind of becoming a great teacher. He has generated these ten aspects of mind. O sons of the victors, such is a beginning bodhisattva.

“O sons of the victors, a beginning bodhisattva such as that should apply himself to receiving instructions on scriptures and recitation. After becoming learned, he should devote himself to retiring into solitude. Having retired into solitude, he should devote himself to pleasing his spiritual teacher. Having pleased his teacher, he should devote himself to being of cheerful speech. Having become of cheerful speech, he should devote himself to awareness of temporality. Lit. “knowing time” (Tib. dus shes pa; Skt. kālajña). Edgerton refers only to the entry for sarvakālajña, which means knowing past, present, and future, but that is too early in the training here. Having become aware of temporality, he should devote himself to fearlessness. Having become fearless, he should devote himself to knowing the meaning. Having become knowledgeable in the meaning, he should devote himself to following the Dharma. Having become a follower of Dharma, he should apply himself to the nature of non-forgetfulness. Having become free of confusion, he should apply himself to formulating the Dharma. Why so? Because upon first generating the thought of awakening he for the most part applies himself with diligence to all the teachings of the Buddha, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the beginning bodhisattva.

(3) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who engages in yogic practice? O sons of the victors this The Comparative Edition notes that the Narthang and Lhasa versions omit ’di la (p. 209). The Stok Palace version also omits ’di la (fol. 158b7). the bodhisattva who engages in yogic practice will understand entities by means of ten aspects of apprehending. What are those ten? They are: (1) understanding all phenomena to be impermanent, (2) understanding all phenomena to be suffering, (3) to be without a self, (4) to be empty, (5) to be immovable, (6) to be without increase, (7) to be not situated, (8) to be nonconceptual, (9) to be effortless, and (10) to be without formation. The bodhisattva should understand these, but since he is a follower of the Dharma, he practices neither application nor non-application.

“O sons of the victors, this is a bodhisattva who engages in yogic practice. O sons of the victors, that bodhisattva who engages in yogic practice should apply himself to investigating the constituents of sentient beings. He should apply himself to investigating dharmadhātu. He should apply himself to investigating the world realm. He should apply himself to investigating the element of earth. He should apply himself to investigating the elements of water, fire, air, and space, and the form and formless realms. Note that the desire realm is found below in the verse restatement. Why is that? It is because he for the most part has direct insight that operates regarding all phenomena, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of a bodhisattva who engages in yogic practice.

(4) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who has taken rebirth? O sons of the victors, a bodhisattva who has taken rebirth is born as exalted in sacred scripture Note that my rendering is tentative since the expression gsung rab ’phags par skyes pa is unknown. thanks to ten purifiers. What are those ten? They are: (1) Not turning back from ultimate reality, (2) accomplishing what will become the highest undivided faith in the Buddha, (3) contemplating the Dharma, (4) investigating sentient beings, (5) investigating the pure lands, (6) investigating the world, (7) investigating deeds, (8) investigating karmic consequences, (9) investigating saṃsāra, and (10) investigating nirvāṇa. A bodhisattva will take rebirth as exalted in sacred scripture thanks to those ten purifiers. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who has taken rebirth.

“O sons of the victors, that bodhisattva who has taken rebirth should apply himself to investigating the equality of the dharmas of all past buddhas, apply himself to investigating the equality of the dharmas of all future buddhas, and apply himself to investigating the equality of the dharmas of all present buddhas. He should apply himself to investigating the equality of the dharmas of all buddhas.

“He should apply himself to the investigation that correctly establishes the dharmas of past buddhas, apply himself to the investigation that correctly establishes the dharmas of future buddhas, and apply himself to the investigation that correctly establishes the dharmas of present buddhas. He should apply himself to the investigation that correctly establishes the dharmas of all buddhas.

“He should apply himself to investigating the equality of the perfection of the qualities of past buddhas, Here and in the next few phrases we should either add du or understand mnyam pa nyid du, “as equality.” apply himself to investigating the equality of the perfection of the qualities of future buddhas, and apply himself to investigating the equality of the perfection of the dharmas of present buddhas. He should apply himself to investigating the equality of the perfection of the dharmas of all buddhas.

“Why is that? It is because he for the most part understands the equality of the three times, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of a bodhisattva who has taken rebirth.

(5) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who has perfected application? O sons of the victors, this bodhisattva who has perfected application will perform whatever virtuous deeds he may undertake for the sake of protecting all sentient beings with the desire to benefit all sentient beings, with the resolve to make all sentient beings happy, with kindness toward all sentient beings, in order to liberate all sentient beings, in order that all sentient beings avoid harm, in order to guide all sentient beings, in order that all sentient beings have faith, in order to train all sentient beings, and in order to cause all sentient beings to enter perfect nirvāṇa. O sons of the victors, this is the bodhisattva who has perfected application.

“O sons of the victors, ten topics ought to be expounded to that bodhisattva who has perfected application. What are they? They are that (1) sentient beings are boundless, (2) inestimable, (3) innumerable, (4) inconceivable, (5) incomparable, (6) immeasurable, (7) empty, (8) immovable, (9) nonexistent, and (10) without nature. Why is that? It is because he for the most part settles his mind in non-attachment, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who has perfected application.

(6) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who has perfected intention? O sons of the victors, this bodhisattva who has perfected intention, if he learns ten factors, will be decisively intent on the qualities of a Buddha. What are those ten? They are: (1) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether or not someone’s discourse praises a buddha, (2) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether one’s discourse praises or does not praise the Dharma, (3) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether someone praises or does not praise bodhisattvas, (4) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether someone praises or does not praise the conduct of bodhisattvas, (5) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether someone teaches that the realm of sentient beings is small or vast in scope, (6) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether someone teaches that the realm of sentient beings is defiled or not, (7) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether someone teaches that the realm of sentient beings is easy or difficult to train, (8) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether someone teaches that dharmadhātu is small or vast in scope, (9) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether someone teaches that the world realms perish or do not perish, and (10) his resolve will be set on the qualities of a buddha regardless of whether someone teaches that dharmadhātu exists or does not exist. O sons of the victors, this is a bodhisattva who has perfected intention.

“O sons of the victors, the bodhisattva who has perfected intention will be taught ten elements that conform with Dharma. What are those ten? He should be taught that all phenomena are: (1) by nature without phenomenal marks, (2) without defining marks, (3) non-entitative, (4) nonexistent, (5) deceptive, (6) isolated, (7) essenceless, (8) illusory, (9) dream-like, and (10) without conceptual thought. Why is that? It is because he largely possesses the quality of increasing the altruistic mind, since it is inalienable, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who has perfected intention.

(7) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who is irreversible? O sons of the victors, the bodhisattva who is irreversible will not turn back from the qualities of a buddha if he learns ten objectives. What are those ten? They are: (1) to not turn back from the qualities of a buddha whether one hears that a buddha exists or does not exist, (2) to not turn back whether one hears that the Dharma exists or does not exist, (3) to not turn back whether one hears that bodhisattvas exist or do not exist, (4) to not turn back whether one hears that the conduct of bodhisattvas exists or does not exist, (5) to not turn back whether one hears that the bodhisattva has reached emancipation in the context of bodhisattva conduct or not, (6) to not turn back whether one hears that the tathāgatas have passed away or have not passed away, (7) to not turn back whether one hears that the tathāgatas have come into the world or not, (8) to not turn back whether one hears that the tathāgatas have presently appeared or not, (9) to not turn back whether one hears that the gnosis of the Buddha is exhausted or is not exhausted, and (10) to not turn back whether one hears that the three times have the same defining mark or that they have dissimilar defining marks.

“O sons of the victors, this is a bodhisattva who is irreversible. O sons of the victors, to that bodhisattva who is irreversible, ten continuities of Dharma should be explained. What are those ten? They are: (1) explaining all phenomena as being the same or different in nature, (2) as being multiple or single in nature, (3) ascribing meanings to letters, (4) ascribing letters to meanings, (5) acribing non-entities to entities, (6) ascribing entities to non-entities, (7) ascribing phenomenal marks to nonexistent phenomenal marks, (8) ascribing nonexistent phenomenal marks to phenomenal marks, (9) ascribing defining marks to non-existent defining marks, and (10) ascribing nonexistent defining marks to defining marks. Why is that? It is because he is for the most part expert in all phenomena and has attained mastery in the way of ripening expertise in all phenomena, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who is irreversible.

(8) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who is still a youth? O sons of the victors, the bodhisattva who is still a youth possesses ten understandings of the Dharma. What are those ten? They are: (1) knowing bodily deeds together with their karmic results, (2) knowing verbal deeds together with their karmic results, (3) knowing mental deeds together with their karmic results, (4) knowing how to obtain a new birth merely by generating the thought to do so, (5) knowing the thoughts of other sentient beings and people and understanding their inclinations, (6) knowing the different realms of sentient beings, (7) knowing the different desire realms, (8) knowing the different form realms, (9) knowing the different formless realms, and (10) swiftly gaining clairvoyance for the sake of beings present in different time periods.

“O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who is still a youth. O sons of the victors, the bodhisattva who is still a youth should be taught ten ways of perfecting the Dharma. What are those ten? They are being correctly shown how to (1) comprehend buddhafields, (2) shake buddhafields, (3) bless buddhafields, (4) investigate buddhafields, (5) journey to buddhafields, (6) journey to countless world realms, (7) ask countless questions, (8) fully achieve a mental body, (9) have measureless translations of words and languages, and (10) accomplish countless buddhafields by generating the thought of doing so. Why is that? It is because he for the most part applies himself to expertise in perfecting things, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who is still a youth.

(9) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who is a regent? O sons of the victors, the bodhisattva who is a regent is expert in ten factors to be understood. What are those ten? They are: (1) expertise in understanding the births of sentient beings, (2) expertise in understanding the flux of the defilements, (3) expertise in understanding the connections of latent tendencies, (4) expertise in understanding the engagement in the object domains, (5) expertise in understanding ultimate reality, (6) expertise in understanding experiences, (7) expertise in understanding the sphere of the world, (8) expertise in understanding the past and the future, (9) expertise in understanding the present, and (10) expertise in understanding the investigation of the relative truth. The Narthang, Lhasa, and Stok Palace versions all have “expertise in understanding the three times” as item 8, “expertise in understanding the relative truth” as item 9, and “expertise in understanding ultimate truth” for item 10. This is important to note, given that the appearance of “exprtise in understanding” (mkhas pa yin) after all three statements suggests that they form a single item in the list, and thus we should prefer the Narthang, Lhasa, and Stok Palace readings. See Comparative Edition, p. 209; Stok Palace, fol. 163b1–3.

“O sons of the victors, this is a bodhisattva who is a regent. O sons of the victors, this bodhisattva who is a regent should be taught ten things. In all editions consulted, only nine things that a bodhisattva who is a regent is to be taught are listed. What are those ten? They consist in being correctly taught: (1) the expertise concerning the royal palace, In the term rgyal po’i pho brang ’khor, the entire expression (including ’khor) means “royal palace.” (2) the modes of conduct in the royal palace, (3) the entering of the royal palace, (4) the investigation of the royal palace, (5) the consecration as a Dharma king, (6) the blessings as a Dharma king, (7) the punishment of the opponents of a Dharma king, (8) the abode of a Dharma king, (9) and the orders of a Dharma king. Why is that? It is because his mind for the most part engages in realization without obscurations regarding all phenomena, and those subjects of learning acquired previously are mastered with his own application and without recourse to dependence on others. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who is a regent.

(10) “O sons of the victors, what is the category of the bodhisattva who has received consecration? O sons of the victors, the bodhisattva who has received consecration possesses ten realizations of knowledge. What are those ten? They consist in: (1) many ways of making innumerable spheres of the world shake, (2) many ways of blessing innumerable spheres of the world, (3) many ways of passing beyond innumerable spheres of the world with a single thought, (4) many ways of purifying innumerable spheres of the world, (5) many ways of making innumerable sentient beings known with a single thought, (6) many ways of viewing innumerable spheres of the world, (7) expertise in investigating the mental activity of innumerable sentient beings with a single thought, (8) expertise in making understood the faculties of innumerable sentient beings with a single thought, (9) expertise in disciplining innumerable sentient beings, and (10) expertise in introducing innumerable sentient beings to the mind of omniscience.

“O sons of the victors, the bodhisattvas on the level of a regent and below cannot know the bodily deeds of the bodhisattva who has received consecration. Nor can they understand his verbal deeds, mental deeds, magical power, or magical vision. Neither do they know how to see what is in past times, nor can they know his karmic conditioning. They do not know how to see with the mind, nor can they know his objects of mind or the sphere of experience of gnosis.

“O sons of the victors, this is the bodhisattva who has received consecration. O sons of the victors, the bodhisattva who has received consecration will be taught ten things by the blessed buddhas. What are these ten? They are: (1) knowing the three times, (2) knowing the Buddhadharma, (3) knowing that the dharmadhātu is indivisible, (4) knowing that the dharmadhātu is without limit and without center, Note that Negi gives dbung (“center”) as a normal synonym of dbus, but it and the verb dbung ba are both archaic spellings. Also, the Comparative Edition indicates that the Yongle, Lithang, Kangxi, Choné, and Lhasa editions all read dbus (p. 210). Interestingly, the Stok Palace edition preserves the archaic spelling dbung (fol. 164b5), suggesting that it is a reading from the Thempangma recension. (5) knowing how to suffuse all the spheres of the world, (6) knowing how to illuminate all the spheres of the world, (7) knowing how to bless all the spheres of the world, (8) thorough knowledge of all sentient beings, (9) clairvoyant knowledge of all phenomena, and (10) the infinite gnosis of the Buddha. Why is that? Because he for the most part applies his mind to knowing everything. O sons of the victors, this is the category of the bodhisattva who has received consecration.”

Immediately after the bodhisattva Dharma­mati explained the ten bodhisattva categories of bodhisattva great beings through the power of the Buddha, world realms numbering as many as the atoms in ten thousand buddhafields shook in every direction. They shook strongly and shook violently. They quaked, quaked strongly, and quaked violently. They trembled, trembled strongly, and trembled violently. They were disturbed, strongly disturbed, and violently disturbed. They shuddered, shuddered strongly, and shuddered violently. And they were agitated, strongly agitated, and violently agitated. This passage consists of repeated verbs with changes in prefixes, which I am choosing to reflect with adverbial modifiers in the English.

By the power of the Buddha and through the attainment of the ultimate nature, a shower of divine flowers poured down from the clouds. From the clouds, there also fell showers of divine incense, of divine fragrance, of divine incense powder, of divine flower garlands, of divine textiles, of divine jewels, of divine lotuses, of divine necklaces, and of divine ornaments. Divine cymbals sounded without being played, divine light shone forth, and divine cheers sounded forth.

In this world with its four continents, and in all world realms, this Dharma teaching pervaded everywhere without omission or repetition, just as in the dwelling place of the king of gods on Mount Meru. And by these very words, this same meaning was taught. Through the power of the Buddha, as many bodhisattvas as there are atoms in ten thousand buddhafields arrived from beyond as many world realms as there are atoms in ten thousand buddhafields. Filling up space throughout the ten directions, they said: “O son of the victors, it is excellent, excellent that you are teaching this ultimate reality of the bodhisattva. O son of the victors, we, too, are all named Dharma­mati. We have come here from world realms called Dharmamegha, from the presence of tathāgatas who are all named Dharma­mati­bhadra. By the blessing-power of the Buddha, this Dharma instruction occurred for all of them; within an audience such as this, the same sense is being expressed by these very words, with nothing added or left out. O son of the victors, we have come under your power, and by the power of the Buddha we all came to this world sphere. And just as we came to this world sphere, so too as many bodhisattvas as there are atoms in ten thousand buddhafields went to the residences of the lords of gods at the peak of Mount Sumeru of all the four-continent worlds in every world sphere throughout the ten directions.”

div.head: Chapter 2
div.p: Then, by the power of the Buddha, the bodhisattva Dharma­mati looked in the ten directions and, after seeing the fully-equipped retinue and the dharmadhātu, spoke these verses:

lg.l: “Having seen the Buddha, who has a mind that is self-arisen and immaculate,
Who possesses beauty and power of body,
And who is ornamented by the mark of the difficult-to-attain practices,

I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening. The phrase byang chub don du brtan pa sems ’jog byed is repeated in many of the verses, though the Stok Palace version largely reads byang chub don du bstan pa sems ’jog byed (“I set my mind on the teachings for the sake of awakening”). See fol. 166a3 for the first occurrence. bstan pa (“teaching”) appears only a couple of times in the editions consulted in the Comparative Edition (p. 210).
“Having seen the Buddha’s matchless magical powers,
Excellent miracles of clairvoyant prophecy, and miracles of insightful instruction,
And having seen living beings of the world with their unbearable suffering,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“Having heard about the qualities of Samanta­bhadra,
The tathāgata who is the source of all qualities,
Unchanging like the sphere of space,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“As many abodes as exist,
And also those other naturally abiding abodes—
To understand them as existing and not otherwise,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“Whatever virtuous and nonvirtuous deeds exist
In the three times—past, present, and future—
For the sake of understanding their causes
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“Absorptions, concentrations, and the practice of emancipations,
And similarly the correct and ultimate meditative accomplishments—
In order to understand them provisionally
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the progressive stages
Of mundane diligence, powers, and faculties
As they really are, each and every one of them,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand numerous treatises
According to the inclinations of the whole world
And out of the three distinct kinds of altruism,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“The various elements in all their varieties,
All of which exist in these three worlds—
In order to understand the nature of those elements
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“That which is omnipresent in this Dharma
And all pervading in any of its virtuous functions—
In order to understand that true reality
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“How all realms arise
And how sentient beings arise from earth—
In order to clearly open the unbound eye
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the types of sentient life
And their characteristics, which existed in the past and still do,
And previously existing lives,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the exhaustion of the defilements,
How they bind sentient beings of the world,
And the bondage to saṃsāra that exists in the world,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the truth of language,
Including all terms that have been coined in the three worlds
And all the forms of mantra that are pathways of speech,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“All phenomena being inexpressible,
In order to understand the ultimate truth
With its empty and unmoving nature and essence,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to display the wonders of the Tathāgata,
Manifesting earthquakes in the worlds
And the violent churnings of oceans,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand as one light
The light rays that spread out in the ten directions
From the tip of every light ray,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“After magically projecting unimaginably numerous worlds
On the surface of my hand,
In order to understand the nature of illusion
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand all phenomena as lifeless,
Placing all the sentient beings in the world
On the palm of my hand without harming them
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“Taking all the water of the great ocean
And converting it into single water drop
In order to ultimately understand it all,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the number of atoms,
Counting all the atomic particles
That exist in all the worlds
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the exhaustion of eons
And the destruction of eons A detailed account of the cosmological eons (Skt. kalpa) is found in the Abhidharmakośa ch. III, stanzas 89–102. in this world in the past
And likewise in the future,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the tathāgatas of the three times
And the nature of the Dharma,
Of the Buddha, of pratyekabuddhas, and of śrāvakas,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the nature of entities,
To bind inexpressibly vast worlds with a hair
And weigh them on a scale,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to better understand coarse and fine,
To bind a ring of unimaginably huge mountains with a hair
And weigh them on the scale,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to display the Buddha’s pure aspects of speech,
To instantly bring about understanding through speech
In all the world realms,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“The words of all the worlds, whatever they may be,
Express momentariness in an instant,
And in order to understand the nature of peace,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“It informs all three worlds
And is known by all sentient beings—
For the sake of understanding the Buddha’s vast, wide tongue,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“As it also has been expressed in all worlds,
The Buddha’s teachings clear away wrong views in a single instant.
In order to understand discursive doctrines,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“Here all worlds are filled with tathāgatas.
To understand in one moment
Such self-originated phenomena,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand the world realms that are like diverse atoms:
Those that are magically emanated in all their aspects and
Those that have arisen from mind,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“All those buddhas of the past as well as those to come,
However many may exist in the world—
In order to understand them in a single moment of thought,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“Though the Buddha speaks a single word, it will never go to waste,
Even with the passing of inconceivably many eons.
In order to understand the division of words,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“In order to understand in a single moment of thought
How living beings of all worlds in all ten directions
Go and how they return,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“Though one may go in all directions,
There is no attachment to anything caused by body, speech, or mind.
In order to understand the three times as empty,
I set my mind firmly on the goal of awakening.
“The thought of awakening, just as it was generated,
Will be made to circulate everywhere for infinite eons.
As for the dictum, ‘One should make offerings in the presence of the buddhas,’
This is the teaching of those who do not turn back.
“The ruler of the world who becomes a son of the victors
In the different worlds of the ten directions
Proclaims what is suitable for anyone—
This is the teaching of those who do not turn back.
“When performing deeds in worldly existence for the sake of awakening,
Such is the bodhisattva’s engagement with happiness.
To constantly express his praise—
This is the teaching of those who do not turn back.
